document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Amazonian species of Syneches Walker (Diptera, Hybotidae, Hybotinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the Amazonian species of Syneches Walker (Diptera, Hybotidae, Hybotinae)

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis . Small, dark brown to black. Antenna with rounded postpedicel, small, less than length of scape and pedicel combined; scutum high and pyramidal. Wing hyaline, pterostigma divided into two brown quadrangular spots, located at end of R 1 and at apex of cell r 1 ; vein R 2 + 3 with apex strongly curved upward forming a right angle with Costa.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 10–16 .
Syneches angulatus
sp. nov.
(paratype). Male terminalia: 10 , epandrium, cerci and hypoproct (dorsal view); 11 , hypandrium, postgonite and phallus (ventral view); 12 , right epandrial lamella (lateral view); 13 , tergite 8; 14 , sternite 8. Female terminalia: 15 , ventral view; 16 , dorsal view. Scale = 0.2 mm.

.

11-22 .iv. 2004
, Henriques, A. Leg / Holótipo,
Syneches angulatus , Menezes & Ale-Rocha
[red label]. Specimen in good condition.

Comments . This species is similar to
S. annulipes Bezzi
,
S. bilobatus
sp. nov.
,
S. maculosum
sp. nov.
,
S . obeliscus
,
S. pyramidatus
and
S. vidali
in the small size ( 2–3.5 mm ), scutum high and pyramidal, dark brown color and slender legs with fore femur slightly dilated on basal half; and is also similar to
S. annulipes
,
S. bilobatus
sp. nov.
,
S. maculosum
sp. nov.
and
S. vidali
in shape of epandrial lamella, phallus and apex of hypandrium. It differs from these species by the wing with pterostigma divided into two brown spots and vein R 2 + 3 with apex strongly curved upwards forming a right angle with C. In
S. vidali
and
S. maculosum
sp. nov.
, the pterostigma is also divided into two spots, but the spot at the end of the vein R 2 + 3 is large, diffuse, and reaches part of cell r 2 + 3 and R 2 + 3 is gradually curved upwards. The female terminalia contributes to the distinction between these species, especially in the shape of tergite and sternite 8 and sternite 10 , which are short, almost square.

Etymology . From the Latin,
angulatus
= angular, in reference to the apex of vein R 2 + 3 strongly curved upwards, forming a right angle with C.
